did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: The Bogucki Family papers

repository.label: Location:
repository.corpname: Connecticut Polish American Archives, Elihu Burritt Library, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Bogucki lived in Philidelphia, PA. They were both educated and very active in many Polish American organizations on the state and national level. In addition to organizing and participating in many events, they supported worthy endeavors related to Polish history, culture, and language.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mr. Alfred S. Bogucki and Mrs. Jadwiga Kulpinski Bogucki were very active in Polish American organizations in the Philadelphia area. Mr. Alfred S. Bogucki, son of Ignacy and Martha Bogucki was born on Dec. 27, 1914. He graduated in 1943 from Temple University with medical degree. Mr. Bogucki served in the U.S. army as a physician and from 1949-1976 he worked for the City of Philadelphia Department of Public Health. He died on Dec. 27, 1980.

Mrs. Jadwiga Kulpinska Bogucki, daughter of Piotr and Florentyna Kulpinski, was born on Oct. 13, 1915 in Philadelphia. Four years later the family returned to Poland for several years and in 1926 returned to Philadelphia and opened the Richmond Bakery. Jadwiga was educated at the Drexel Institute of Technology and received her Masters degree in Home Economics. She then went into teaching at college and high school level. While at Drexel she joined Polish Intercollegiate Club (PKM) and learned to play tennis. Jadwiga became the first PKM tennis tournament champion in 1936. She was active in the club for several decades and held various positions. After marrying Alfred, she became a housewife and together with her husband was very active in many Polish-American organizations in the Philadelphia area. Mr. and Mrs. Bogucki have one son Peter, who was born on March 11, 1954. Mrs. Bogucki's special interest was in education, Polish culture and language. She was tireless advocate of keeping Polish heritage alive and this translated into cultivating Polish traditions and language. The Boguckis organized events and participated in the Polish People's University, Paderewski Choral Society, Pulaski Day Parade, Kosciuszko Foundation, and the Polish American Historical Association. Mr. and Mrs. Bogucki were deeply religious and were among the initial group of volunteers who helped to establish the National Shrine of Czestochowa in Doylestown, PA. Mrs. Jadwiga Bogucki died on July 19, 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of personal and organizational correspondence, anniversary booklets, and pamphlets. Since the Boguckis' actively participated in activities of many organizations, their papers include broad documentation of activities of organizations such as, Polish Intercollegiate Club (PKM), Polish Heritage Society of Philadelphia, Polish People's University, Polish American Historical Association, and several others. There is also a large amount of news clippings from various events in the Philadelphia area from the 1930's till late 1990's. Mrs. Bogucki was interested in preservation and teaching of the Polish language, therefore the collection has many pamphlets and publication related to language instruction.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: The Bogucki Family papers (CPAA 05-05). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

acqinfo.p: Two donations were made by Peter Bogucki son of Jadwiga and Alfred Bogucki in 2005, and third part of materials was donated after Mrs. Bogucki death in December of 2009.

processinfo.p: Material was processed by Renata Vickrey.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in the collection is arranged by date and by organization.
